I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
policy-based loan to the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) for subprogram 2 of the Public 
Sector Program.1 
 
2. 
The  program,  supported  by  a  policy-based  loan,  will  improve  the  long-term  fiscal 
sustainability of the Government of the Marshall Islands. In 2010, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  approved  (i) a  program  cluster  for  the  public  sector  program  and  (ii)  financing  from  the 
Asian Development Fund (ADF) of $9.5 million (SDR6,413,000) for subprogram 1 of the public 
sector  program.2 The  public  sector  program  supports  the  implementation  of  the  government’s 
reform initiatives and initiates the adjustments required to achieve long-term fiscal sustainability. 
Under subprogram 1, policy actions were designed and the implementation of immediate reform 
priorities began. Subprogram 2 will complete the implementation of the policy actions. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The  RMI  consists  of  29  low-lying  atolls  and  five  single  islands  that  cover  181  square 
kilometers of land area spread across nearly 5 million square kilometers of the western Pacific 
Ocean.  The  country  gained  independence  in  1979,  having  been  administered  by  the  United 
States  (US)  as  part  of  the  Trust  Territory  of  the  Pacific  Islands  since  1947.  The  2011  census 
recorded a total population of 53,158 persons, with approximately 74% of the population living 
on Majuro and Ebeye.3 ADB has identified the RMI as a fragile situation since 2008; among the 
constraints  that  underlie  weak  performance  and  fragility  are  weak  public  sector  institutions, 
limited government capacity, and underdeveloped governance systems.4 
 
The  RMI  economy  relies  heavily  on  government  expenditure  and,  in  turn,  on  foreign 
4. 
grants,  which  fund  more  than  two-thirds  of  government  expenditure.  Most  foreign  grants  are 
provided  by  the  US,  mainly  under  the  amended  Compact  of  Free  Association. 5  Increased 
foreign grants helped the economy grow at an average annual rate of 3.1% in FY2000–FY2007. 
However, the economy contracted by 1.9% in FY2008 and 1.3% in FY2009, as high world food 
and  fuel  prices  raised  inflation  to  14.7%,  prompting  the  declaration  of  a  state  of  national 
economic emergency. The economy grew by 5.2% in FY2010, driven by an expansion of fishery 
output  and  exports,  and  moderating fuel  prices. Similarly,  growth in FY2011  was  5.0%,  driven 
by  bigger  fish  catches,  large  inflows  from  the  Kwajalein  land  use  agreement,  and the  Federal 
Aviation Administration-funded airport extension project (Table 1).

 In 2009, recognizing the need for reform, the RMI government began  several initiatives 
7. 
to advance public sector reform and promote  macroeconomic stability and sustainable growth. 
These  included  the  preparation  of  a  comprehensive  recovery  plan  for  the  Marshalls  Energy 
Company (MEC) and the formation of the Comprehensive Adjustment Program (CAP) Advisory 
Group  and  the  Tax  and  Revenue  Reform  and  Modernization  (TRAM)  Commission  to  prepare 
fiscal reform plans.8 These initiatives formed the basis of the government’s strategy to mitigate 
the impact of the global financial crisis and subsequently led to the design of ADB’s support for 
the public sector program (footnote 2). 
 
8. 
Subprogram  1 supported  the  design  and  initial  implementation  of  reforms  to  rectify  the 
situation  in  which  the  government  found  itself  in  2008  and  2009.  The  subprogram  was 
implemented successfully by the government and had a positive outcome by putting in place a 
solid  foundation  on  which  to  begin  the  implementation  of  further  reforms  under  subprogram 2. 
Beginning  in  2009,  and  continuing  throughout  the  implementation  of  the  program,  the  policy 
conditions of subprogram 1 have stabilized the fiscal situation, particularly in the areas of debt 
and expenditure management. 
 
Under  subprogram  1,  the  government  onlent  the  majority  of  loan  funds  to  MEC.9 The 
9. 
funds were used to repay a high-interest loan held by MEC with a commercial bank. Using the 
cash-flow savings from repaying this loan, MEC was able to refurbish a generator and achieve a 
significantly higher megawatt output, which reduced fuel usage by about 14%. 
 
10. 
Subprogram  1  included  several  covenants  concerning  the  rationalization  of  MEC,  of 
which the onlending arrangement between the government and MEC was critical in contributing 
to  MEC’s  long-term  commercial  and  financial  stability.10 Under  subprogram 1,  the  government 
was required to (i) ensure that a subsidiary loan agreement was executed between the Ministry 
of  Finance  (MOF)  and  MEC,  (ii)  establish  a  sinking  fund  account  at  a  commercial  bank  to 
accumulate  funds  to  service  its  repayment  obligations  under  the  loan  agreement,  (iii)  ensure 
that MEC makes automatic monthly payments into the sinking fund account, and (iv) ensure that 
MOF had the first priority right to receive payments from other assets of MEC in the event of a 
default in the obligation of MEC to contribute to the sinking fund account. In addition, the loan 
agreement  required  MEC  to  (i)  open  a  separate  account  at  a  commercial  bank  dedicated  to 
repair  and  maintenance  funds;  and  (ii)  make  automatic  monthly  payments  into  the  repair  and 
maintenance account from its revenue accounts, to be used exclusively for repair, maintenance, 
procurement of spare parts, materials, and equipment (and related labor costs) directly related 
to power generation and distribution. The government has complied with these covenants. 
 
11. 
The  program  is  aligned with  the  RMI  country  operations  business  plan  (COBP),  2012–
2014 and ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2010–2014. It also applies lessons from earlier ADB policy 
programs in the RMI and elsewhere in the Pacific, as well as ADB’s approach to engaging with 
weakly  performing  countries,  notably  by  (i)  adopting  a  country-led  set  of  policy  actions 
developed in an open, participatory manner and at a pace in keeping with country practices, and 
(ii) initiating long-term policy dialogue and providing targeted technical assistance (TA).

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

12. 
The impact will be that the public sector provides more efficient and effective services to 
the population. The outcome will be that the government achieves fiscal sustainability. For the 
purposes  of  the  program,  fiscal  sustainability  is  defined  as  the  Compact  trust  fund  being  on 
track to replace Compact grants in FY2024. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

13. 
Output  1:  Government’s  fiscal  discipline  improves  over  the  medium  term.  Under 
subprogram  1,  the  cabinet  endorsed  budget  targets  for  FY2011  and  FY2012  to  bring  budget 
outcomes in line with International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommendations. The key target was 
a  budget  surplus  large  enough  to  fund  RMI  contributions  to  the  Compact  trust  fund. 
Complementary  targets  were  set  for  other  budget  items,  including  civil  servant  wages  and 
salaries, grants and transfers, capital expenditure, and tax revenue. The cabinet also endorsed 
debt management guidelines for the government and SOEs. 
 
14. 
Under  subprogram  2,  these  budget  targets  were  to  be  implemented  over  FY2011  and 
FY2012, and fiscal restraint was to be maintained in the preparation of the budget for FY2013. 
To  improve  fiscal  discipline,  subprogram  2  also  requires  adoption  of  a  public  sector  debt 
management strategy and fiscal responsibility legislation, through an amendment to the existing 
Financial Management Act, 1990. 
 
15. 
The  government  does  not  have  a  medium-term  debt  management  strategy,  and  it  has 
recognized that it needs to adopt a more comprehensive and integrated approach to ensure that 
debt  is  maintained  at  sustainable  levels.  The  debt  management  strategy  will  provide  the 
government  with  a  path  to  restore  debt  sustainability,  define  its  debt  management  objectives, 
set  risk  management  strategies,  and  reduce  the  future  financial  burden  of  meeting  its  debt 
obligations. The existing Financial Management Act defines the general principles of managing 
government finances but does not contain provisions for debt management. The amendment to 
the act will therefore incorporate key components of the debt management policy. 
 
The budget targets set under subprogram 1, and implemented under subprogram 2, are 
16. 
to be achieved through the actions of outputs 2 and 3, which are designed to restrain recurrent 
expenditure and increase tax revenue. The medium-term direction underlying the program is an 
increase  in  the  budget  surplus  to  5%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  by  FY2016,  as 
recommended by the IMF (footnote 6). 
 
17. 
Output 2: Cabinet enforces restraint on recurrent expenditure. Under subprogram 1, 
the  CAP  Advisory  Group  prepared  an  independent  review  of  public  expenditure.  The  cabinet 
endorsed the CAP Advisory Group report and the actions recommended by the group to restrain 
recurrent  expenditure.  These  included  removing  funding  for  50  vacant  positions  in  the  civil 
service;  reducing  compensation  paid  to  landowners  for  MEC’s  access  to  their  land;  and 
reducing the government's administrative expenditure on housing leases and rentals, electricity, 
water,  communications,  vehicles,  fuel,  and  professional  services.  In  addition,  a  freeze  on  the 
government’s wage and salary bill, compensation paid to members of the Parliament (Nitijela), 
and  housing  allowances  for  public  officials,  was  recommended  by  the  CAP  Advisory  Group.

Subprogram 1 also supported workforce audits in three major ministries—education, health, and 
public works—to guide efforts to raise the productivity of the civil service.11 
 
18. 
Under subprogram 2, these expenditure targets were to be met through the FY2011 and 
FY2012  budgets.  The  government  made  general  across-the-board  cuts  to  expenditure  in 
FY2010  (5.0%),  FY2011  (5.5%),  and  FY2012  (budgeted  expenditure  maintained  at  FY2011

however,  this  approach  resulted  in  the  majority  of  targets  being  met.  Subprogram 2  also 
extends  the  workforce  audits  to  five  more  ministries  and  agencies—finance,  foreign  affairs, 
internal  affairs,  attorney-general’s  office,  and  resources  and  development—as  well  as  the 
Nitijela,  and  begins  actions  to  implement  the  findings  in  conjunction  with  the  Public  Service 
Commission. 
 
Output  3:  Ministry  of  Finance  increases  tax  revenue.  Under  subprogram 1,  the

20. 
Subprogram  2  requires  implementation  of  the  tax  reforms  as  recommended  by  the 
TRAM Commission. The commission recommended replacing an array of existing taxes with a 
modern  tax  regime  that  has  higher  revenue  potential.  The  proposed  new  taxes  are  a 
consumption tax, an excise tax for certain goods (such as alcohol and fuel), a net profit tax for 
large businesses, and a modified wages and salaries tax. These will replace hotel taxes, import 
duties,  various  local  taxes,  and  gross  revenue  taxes  (except  those  on  small  businesses).  The 
new taxes are designed to reduce distortions facing producers and consumers. The commission 
also recommended changes to the income tax by removing exemptions and adopting a tax-free 
threshold  to  reduce  its  regressive  aspects,  and  to  improve  tax  administration  by  unifying  tax 
administration, strengthening tax audits, and harmonizing tax collection processes. 
 
21. 
The  Pacific  Financial  Technical  Assistance  Centre  has  been  providing  support  to  the 
government  in  this  area.  Under  subprogram  2,  legislation  was  introduced  into  Parliament  in 
September 2012. The Australian Agency for International Development has recruited an advisor 
for MOF (Division of Customs, Treasury, Revenue and Taxation) to successfully implement the 
reforms over a 2-year period. Actions under way to improve tax administration focus on tax-filing 
assistance and tax payment, audit and investigations, objections and appeals, management of 
delinquent taxpayers, and considering more efficient information technology systems. The level 
of  taxpayer  noncompliance  is  high,  and  relatively  simple  efforts  to  improve  tax  filing  and 
payment should yield solid revenue gains.12 
 
22. 
Raising  compliance  through  more  rigorous  tax  administration  is  expected  to  generate 
most  of  the  additional  tax  revenue  targeted  under  the  program,  as  the  new  taxes  should  be 
largely revenue-neutral for existing taxpayers in the short-term. The medium-term target is to lift 
the ratio of taxes to GDP to 16.2% in FY2015, from 14.3% in FY2011, as the IMF recommended.

of the responsible minister, the principle objective for the operation of SOEs, community service

be  incorporated  into  an SOE  act.  Also  under  subprogram  2,  strategic  reform  plans  have been 
prepared  for  the  Majuro  Water  and  Sewer  Company,  Marshall  Islands  Shipping  Corporation, 
and Tobolar Copra Processing Authority, and action is under way to implement the plans.14

Poverty and Social 

39. 
The  program  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  in  several  ways.  First,  better  fiscal 
management  will  reduce fiscal  deficits;  improve the  capacity to deal  with external  shocks;  and 
create a foundation for sustainable, equitable, and inclusive pro-poor economic growth. Second, 
revenue enhancement will enable the government to make transfers to the Compact trust fund, 
allowing a smooth transition to the post-Compact era, which could otherwise create social and 
economic tension as public expenditure and employment shrink and as poverty and deprivation 
worsen.  Third,  improving  the  efficiency  of  SOEs,  especially  MEC,  will  reduce  the  burden  that 
cash transfers place on the budget, and make additional resources available for development.22
